Recently, I've been reading John Pomfret's book THE BEAUTIFUL COUNTRY AND THE MIDDLE KINGDOM, which looks at the US-China relationship over a longer period of time, going back to 1776.  The book has raised my interest in the long history of US misunderstandings about Chinese political dynamics and intentions.  Time and again US players have seen what they want to see in China, and missed the reality.  With the distracting blizzard of Trump tweet commentary, perhaps today's big mistake is to see the North Korea problem as a North Korea problem, when it appears to be a China problem.  China's expansionist strategy has many elements, including claims to the South China Sea, naval base construction in the Indian Ocean, recent border clashes with India and relentless pressure on US affiliates including the Philippines, South Korea and Japan.   If China's strategic goal is to break apart the structure that has controlled the Western Pacific region since the end of WW II, North Korea is simply China's useful dog in this campaign.  China's ideal preferred end game would include:  (1) tractable vassal states in Japan, Philippines, Vietnam that have no alliance with the United States.  (2) restoration of Taiwan and various perimeter island chains as China possessions,  (3) reunification of the Korean peninsula under a socialist or communist political regime that China would dominate, and (4) Chinese control of the Eastern hemisphere to a degree that would be similar to what the Monroe Doctrine once was in the Western Hemisphere.  If this is the great game being played, six party talks would be a farce, and no progress will come from getting in a room one-on-one with Kim.

Going to depart from the crowd and give this a slight chance based on some previous expression of reviving the six-party talks by parties or likely parties to the discussion.  Sure, I've given it only 2% but sometimes it's about the psychology about foregone conclusions and how a mind shift, even of a minority, precedes realization or manifestation.

"Bruce Klingner and Sue Mi Terry in WaPo: “This month, we were part of a group of delegates from the United States, Japan, China and South Korea who met in Sweden with representatives of North Korea to explore possible grounds for resuming the six-party talks that collapsed in 2009. After many hours with the North Korean delegation at these ‘1.5 track’ talks, we left more pessimistic than when we arrived. North Korean officials made unambiguously clear that Pyongyang will not be deterred from augmenting its nuclear arsenal or test-launching an intercontinental ballistic missile that could eventually threaten the U.S. homeland. There were no signals of flexibility or willingness to negotiate on these programs. Throughout, the North Korean message was that denuclearization is off the table.” http://wapo.st/2tVpt13

I don't think this will be happening any time soon. The recent aggression between the US and North Korea seems to have calmed making  the talks seems less necessary, at least for the time being. While another missile or nuclear test might cause tension to rise again, but it will again take time for tensions to rise high enough to force all 6 nations to convene. Also, I have some difficulty believing that either Trump Kim Jong Un will compromise to each other's terms in order to talk.  Looking at it from Kim Jong Un's perspective, I don't see what would be gained from such talks other than giving him more time to develop ICBM technology. After all, Gaddafi gave up his weapons of mass destruction and nearly a decade later NATO helped in his downfall

There is a better chance that a four-way (US/China/South Korea/NK) or five way (US/China/South Korea/NK/Japan) talk may happen sooner rather than a six way talk including Russia. The current complications with Russian aggression in eastern Ukraine and their support for Asad in Syria will "muddy" the nuclear talks with North Korea as it can be over as leverage. Additionally, the six-party talks have failed in the past because North Korea often reneges on their obligations and because each respective country wants to forward their interests in the region by-way-of using the North Korean Nuclear situation to their advantage.

Sec. of State Rex Tillerson has bluntly stated the 20 year strategy of "strategic patience" has ended. Paired with the fact that POTUS will have far less tolerance for such muscle flexing and a statement by Niki Haley indicating no interest in resuming the SPTs as they have "been there and done that" it appears unlikely that any attempt at coordination from the US is unlikely. The Chinese will not engage without using NK as a bargaining chip, SK is too weakened politically from its Presidential scandal to embark on any serious foreign policy initiatives and the Russians have shown zero interest since the fall of 2016 in solving this issue. In fact, it may work in their favor given how it distracts the world from their meddling across EE and the ME. Japan is the only power that may want to invite a détente but without China or the US in their corner, the likelihood is below 10%.

The Six Party Talks at the beginning of the 21st century were a failure partially due to the fact that the US and western allies had little to gain in the ratification of the NPT by the DPRK.  Considering the instability of the rogue state, any agreement signed would prove to be temporary. For those reasons, I think it is very unlikely that any diplomatic talks will resume.
